questions.question: Question 1: 'a' wave in JVP corresponds to?
questions.explanation:
The "a" wave in jugular venous pressure (JVP) is a positive wave, which corresponds to right atrial 
contraction. The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are: • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just 
before the first heart sound. • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular 
systole. • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole. • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound. • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid 
valve opening. 789 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: The c wave seen in a normal JVP waveform represents?

options.a: Bulging of tricuspid valve into the right atrium
options.c: Venous filling of the right atrium
options.d: Emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle

questions.explanation:
The c-wave in a JVP waveform represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium 
during ventricular systole. JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. The waveforms seen in a normal JVP are: • a wave corresponds to atrial contraction and occurs just after the P wave (on ECG) and just 
before the first heart sound. • c wave represents the bulging of the tricuspid valve into the right atrium during ventricular 
systole. • x descent corresponds to the atrial relaxation during atrial diastole. • v wave represents atrial filling during ventricular systole and peaks at the second heart sound. • y descent represents passive emptying of the right atrium into the right ventricle after tricuspid 
valve opening. 790 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: The following abnormality on a JVP waveform can be seen in which of the given conditions? 779 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given waveform shows a cannon ‘a’ wave seen in ventricular tachycardia. It occurs since atria 
contract against a closed tricuspid valve in ventricular tachycardia. JVP measured in the internal jugular vein is a reflection of the right atrial pressure. Note: Giant/prominent a-waves occur during every beat while cannon a-waves result from 
arrhythmias, therefore, are usually intermittent. The ECG is helpful to look for rhythm 
disturbances that are associated with cannon a-waves whereas echocardiography can be used to 
assess structural defects (of right atrium) that are associated with giant a-waves. 791 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 4: A 37-year-old male patient comes to the clinic with complaints of weakness, restlessness, and 
chest pain. On examination, his blood pressure is found to be 90/60 mmHg, his heart sounds 
are muffled, and his neck veins are distended. What is the typical JVP finding in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Hypotension, soft or absent heart sounds, and jugular venous distention (Beck’s triad) are the 
three principal features of cardiac tamponade. The typical JVP finding here is absent y-descent. JVP shows a prominent x (early systolic) descent and an absent y (early diastolic) descent because 
of the ventricle's limited or absent early diastolic filling. JVP is almost always elevated in cardiac 
tamponade and may be associated with venous distention in the forehead and scalp. There may be reductions in the amplitude of the QRS complexes, and electrical alternans of the P, 
QRS, or T waves in cardiac tamponade. Note: Alternation of QRS complexes, usually in a 2:1 ratio, on ECG is called electrical alternans. It 
is caused by the movement of the heart in the pericardial space. Electrical alternans is also seen in 
patients with myocardial ischemia, acute pulmonary embolism, and tachyarrhythmias.

questions.question: Question 5: Deep y descent in JVP is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
The y-descent in jugular venous pulse (JVP) corresponds to the fall in right atrial pressure after 
the tricuspid valve opening in the early diastolic phase of the right ventricle. Y-descent is 
attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of resistance to ventricular filling in the early 
diastole. Other options: Options B and C: Restrictive cardiomyopathy and constrictive pericarditis can have deep y descent 
due to rapid filling of the right ventricle during early diastole. Option D: In patients with tricuspid regurgitation, increased blood flow to the right atria through 
the incompetent tricuspid valve during ventricular systole results in a prominent v wave. When 
the tricuspid valve opens during ventricular diastole, this increased blood in the right atria enters 
rapidly into the right ventricle during early diastole resulting in deep y-descent. 792 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: The following four patients were examined on a tilt table for postural hypotension. The blood 
pressures before and immediately after performing head-up tilt are given below. Choose the 
correct option regarding the patients who suffer from orthostatic hypotension.
questions.explanation:
Orthostatic hypotension is defined as a reduction in systolic blood pressure of at least 20 
mmHg or diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mmHg within 3 min of standing or head-up tilt on 
a tilt table. On standing, blood is displaced to the lower extremities, causing a drop in the venous return to 
the heart. This drop leads to a decrease in cardiac output and stimulation of compensatory 
mechanisms which trigger a reflex increase in sympathetic (vasoconstrictor) outflow. Orthostatic 
hypotension is a manifestation of sympathetic (autonomic) failure. Symptoms include light-headedness, dizziness, and presyncope (near-faintness) in response to 
sudden postural change.

questions.question:
Question 7: 780 
Sold by @itachibot Pulsus paradoxus is seen in all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Pulsus bisferiens is seen in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, not pulsus paradoxus. Pulsus paradoxus refers to the fall in systolic pressure by > 10 mmHg with inspiration. It is an 
exaggeration of the normal response. It is seen in the following conditions: • Cardiac tamponade • Massive pulmonary embolism • Hemorrhagic shock • Obstructive lung disease • Tension pneumothorax

questions.question: Question 8: Pulsus bisferiens is seen in all of the following conditions except:
questions.explanation:
Pulsus alternans (characterized by alternating strong and weak beats) is seen in left ventricular 
dysfunction. Pulsus bisferiens is a bifid pulse with two systolic peaks. It is seen in the following conditions: • Advanced aortic regurgitation (AR) • Aortic stenosis (AS) with AR • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 793 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Water hammer pulse is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Water hammer pulse, also known as Corrigan’s pulse, is characterized by a sharp rise and a rapid 
fall-off and is seen in aortic regurgitation (AR) due to the fact that arterial pressure falls rapidly in 
late systole and early diastole. In AR, the pulse pressure is widened due to systolic hypertension and decreased diastolic 
pressure. The diastolic pressure is measured at Korotkoff phase IV. In certain patients with AR or 
a combination of aortic stenosis (AS) and AR, the carotid arterial pulse may exhibit a bisferiens 
pattern, characterized by two systolic waves separated by a trough. The apical impulse is heaving and displaced inferiorly. A diastolic thrill may be palpable along the 
left sternal border. A2 is usually absent in AR. An early diastolic murmur can be auscultated in chronic AR. It is best 
heard in the third intercostal space along the left sternal edge. 794 
Sold by @itachibot Severe AS (Option A) would show pulsus parvus et tardus, characterized by the carotid pulse 
rising slowly to a delayed peak. Chronic mitral regurgitation (Option D) shows a sharp, low volume upstroke due to reduced 
cardiac output and acute mitral regurgitation demonstrates narrow pulse pressure.

questions.question: Question 10: A loud S1 is associated with?
questions.explanation:
Rheumatic mitral stenosis is associated with loud S1. The greater the distance the valve travels to close, the louder is the sound. Increased left atrial 
pressures in rheumatic mitral stenosis force the mobile portion of the mitral valve leaflets far 
apart such that they are forced closed from a relatively far distance, resulting in a loud S1. In 
calcific mitral stenosis, leaflet mobility is poor, and they are not separated by a large distance, 
resulting in a soft S1. Loud S1 is heard in the following: • Short PR intervals • Early stages of mitral stenosis as long as the valves are pliable • Atrial myxoma • High output states • Tachycardia Soft S1 is heard in the following: • Mitral regurgitation • Aortic regurgitation • Long PR intervals • Calcified Mitral stenosis 795 
Sold by @itachibot • Left ventricular contractile dysfunction • Beta-receptor blockers • Pericardial effusion, obesity, COPD- due to decreased conduction through the chest wall

questions.question:
Question 11: 781 
Sold by @itachibot A hypertensive patient presented with chest pain and was found to have dilated 
cardiomyopathy on an echocardiogram. On auscultation, a reversed splitting of second heart 
sound was heard. Which of the following could most likely be responsible for the same?
questions.explanation:
Reversed (or paradoxical) splitting refers to the situation when P2 is heard before A2. This is seen 
in the following: • LBBB • HOCM • Right ventricular pacing • Severe AS • Acute myocardial ischemia

questions.question: Question 12: Disappearance of loud S1 in mitral stenosis occurs in all except:
questions.explanation:
Loud S1 is heard in mild mitral stenosis (MS). The intensity of S1 depends on the distance over which the anterior leaflet of the mitral valve 
moves, leaflet mobility, LV contractility, and PR interval. It is independent of the severity of MS. Loud S1 is seen in early rheumatic MS, short PR interval, and hyperdynamic circulatory states. S1 becomes soft in case of calcified leaflets, long PR interval, associated aortic regurgitation and 
LV dysfunction.

questions.question:
Question 13: While examining a patient, you hear a widely split S2 on auscultation. Which of the following 
is not a possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
A wide split of S2 is not seen in the left bundle branch block (LBBB), however paradoxical 
splitting is seen. S2 is normally heard as A2-P2. This split is exaggerated in conditions that cause early aortic valve 
closure or delayed pulmonary valve closure. Option A: In atrial septal defect (ASD), left ventricle (LV) ejection time decreases due to the 
shunting of the blood from the left atrium (LA) to the right atrium leading to early aortic valve 
closure. Option B: In mitral regurgitation (MR), due to the regurgitation of blood from the LV to the LA, 
the LV ejection time decreases leading to early aortic valve closure. Option C: In pulmonary stenosis (PS), the delayed closure of pulmonary valves leads to the 
splitting of S2. 796 
Sold by @itachibot Wide splitting of S2 is also heard in RBBB and LV pacing.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following conditions is associated with a fixed wide splitting of S2?
questions.explanation:
Fixed wide splitting of S2 is seen in atrial septal defect (ASD). The ASD creates a left to right shunt that increases the blood flow to the right side of the heart. 
This causes the pulmonary valve to close later than the aortic valve independent of 
inspiration/expiration.

questions.question:
Question 16: An ECG of a patient who underwent pulmonary artery catheterization showed a right bundle 
branch block. On auscultation, a widely split S1 was observed. Which of the following is true 
regarding this auscultatory finding?

options.c: The split remains constant with inspiration and expiration
options.d: The change in split depends on the degree of bundle branch block

questions.explanation:
In a patient with a right bundle branch block (RBBB), there's a widely split S1 which increases 
with inspiration. S1 is normally heard as a single sound. Any delay in the closure of the tricuspid valve or early 
closure of the mitral valve produces a split in S1. During inspiration, venous return to the right 797 
Sold by @itachibot atrium increases. Therefore, the atria take a longer time to empty into the ventricles delaying the 
closure of the tricuspid valve. This increases the split in S1 during inspiration. In a patient with an 
RBBB, the tricuspid valve closure is further delayed leading to a wide split in S1.

questions.question:
Question 17: A 23-year-old woman presents with a history of occasional palpitations. She has no history of 
chest pain or dyspnea. On examination, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, the pulse is 82/min 
and regular. Joint hypermobility and thoracolumbar scoliosis are present. Gorlin's sign is 
positive. On auscultation, a click is heard after S1, followed by a late systolic murmur. What is 
the probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The probable diagnosis of the above scenario is Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (EDS). EDS is a group of clinically and genetically heterogeneous connective tissue disorders. Typical 
presenting features include joint hypermobility, skin hyperextensibility, and tissue fragility. EDS 
type 6 is also characterized by scoliosis. Gorlin’s sign refers to the ability of patients 
of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome to touch the tip of the nose with the tip of their tongue. Mitral valve prolapse (MVP) is a frequent finding in patients with EDS. An early systolic click 
which may be followed by a late systolic murmur is the auscultatory finding heard in MVP.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not a diastolic sound?
questions.explanation:
The ejection click is a systolic sound. Ejection clicks are high-pitched sounds that occur at the moment of the maximal opening of the 
aortic or pulmonary valves. They are heard just after the first heart sound. Ejection clicks occur in: • Non-calcific aortic or pulmonary stenosis • Aortic or pulmonary root dilatation • Congenital bicuspid aortic or pulmonary valves Nonejection clicks, which occur after the onset of the carotid upstroke, are related to the mitral 
valve prolapse.

questions.question:
Question 19: On auscultation of a patient, you hear a murmur between S1 and S2. Which of the following 
conditions is not likely to be associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
A murmur occurring between S1 and S2 is a systolic murmur. Pulmonary regurgitation produces a 
diastolic murmur. The causes of systolic murmurs are as follows: • Mid-systolic- aortic stenosis, pulmonic stenosis, ASD, HOCM. • Holosystolic/pansystolic- mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, VSD. • Late systolic- mitral valve prolapse. The causes of diastolic murmurs are as follows: • Early diastolic- aortic regurgitation, pulmonic regurgitation. 798 
Sold by @itachibot • Mid/late diastolic- mitral stenosis, tricuspid stenosis, Austin-Flint. The causes of continuous murmurs are as follows: • Patent ductus arteriosus (machinery or Gibson's murmur). • Venous hum • AV fistula • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm

questions.question:
Question 20: While examining a patient, you hear a mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation on 
auscultation of the precordium. Which of the following condition is associated with this 
finding?
questions.explanation:
A mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation and an opening snap is typically seen in 
mitral stenosis. The presystolic accentuation is due to the atrial contraction forcing blood through the stenosed 
mitral valve. The presystolic accentuation disappears in atrial fibrillation. Option A: Mitral regurgitation presents with a holosystolic murmur, best heard at the apex with 
radiation to the left axilla. Option B: Mitral valve prolapse presents with an early systolic click followed by a late systolic 
murmur is heard. Option C: Aortic stenosis presents with a harsh crescendo-decrescendo ejection systolic murmur 
heard best at the right upper sternal border, with radiation of the murmur to the carotid arteries.

questions.question:
Question 21: You are a part of a health camp conducting check-ups for cardiovascular ailments. On 
auscultation of a patient's precordial area, you hear a systolic murmur. On asking the patient 
to perform the following maneuver, the intensity of the murmur increased. Which of the 
following conditions is associated with this finding? 784 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows the Valsalva maneuver. The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy 
(HCM) increases in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver. The murmurs produced by TR (tricuspid regurgitation), AS (aortic stenosis), and MR (mitral 
regurgitation) decrease in intensity while performing the Valsalva maneuver. Note: Valsalva maneuver decreases the intensity of all murmurs except MVP (mitral valve 
prolapse) and HCM.

questions.question:
Question 22: While auscultating a patient's precordium, a murmur was heard that decreased in intensity 
on performing the following sustained maneuver. Which of the given condition is associated 
with this finding?
questions.explanation:
The above image shows a sustained handgrip maneuver. The murmur of aortic stenosis decreases 
in intensity during sustained handgrip. Maneuvers like sustained handgrip, simultaneous inflation of blood pressure cuffs above the 
systolic in both upper limbs, and infusion of vasopressors increase the systemic vascular 
resistance (afterload). Since increasing afterload will prevent blood from flowing in a normal 
forward path, it will increase any murmurs that are due to backward flowing blood and decresase 
the ones due to forward blood flow. 799 
Sold by @itachibot Murmurs that increase in intensity on sustained handgrip: • Mitral regurgitation • Ventricular septal defect • Aortic regurgitation Murmurs that decrease in intensity on sustained handgrip: • Aortic stenosis • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.question: Question 23: Which of the following murmur increases on standing?
questions.explanation:
The murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM) increases with standing, as there is a 
reduction in preload. In conditions of reduced preload, there is lesser end diastolic volume in the 
left ventricle, leading to a narrower outflow tract, and a louder murmur is heard. The murmur heard in HOCM is a mid-systolic murmur, which is loudest along the left sternal 
border. It increases in conditions of decreased preload and afterload (standing, valsalva, vagal 
maneuvers) or conditions of increased contractility (inotropic stimulation) and decreases when 
preload and afterload are increased (squatting, vasopressors). Most murmurs decrease in intensity with reduced preload and afterload except HOCM and mitral 
valve prolapse (MVP).

questions.question:
Question 24: A child was being evaluated for an underlying cardiac defect. On auscultation, a murmur was 
heard which began in systole, enveloped the second heart sound, and continued through 
some portion of the diastole. Which of the following condition is not associated with this 
finding?

options.a: Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation

questions.explanation:
The murmur described above is a continuous murmur. A continuous murmur is produced when there is a pressure gradient between the cardiac 
chambers or the blood vessels throughout the systole and diastole. Continous murmurs are 
characterised by the flow of blood in the same direction and through the same channel during 
systole and diastole. These murmurs begin in systole, envelope the second heart sound (S2), and 
continue through some portion of diastole. Conditions producing a continuous murmur: • Patent ductus arteriosus • Venous hum • AV fistula • Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm Ventricular septal defect with aortic regurgitation does not produce a continuous murmur. It 
produces a systolic-diastolic murmur as the blood flows through different channels during systole 
and diastole. These murmurs do not envelope S2. 800 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is true about Gallavardin effect?

options.a: It is associated with a diastolic murmur
options.b: It is seen in aortic stenosis
options.c: It refers to the radiation of murmur to the carotids
options.d: The transmission makes the murmur low pitched

questions.explanation:
The Gallavardin effect refers to the phenomenon of the transmission of the mid-systolic murmur 
of aortic stenosis to the apex where it becomes higher pitched.

questions.question:
Question 26: 786 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presents with easy fatiguability and shortness of breath on moderate physical 
activity. On auscultation, a holosystolic murmur is heard over the lower left sternal border 
and radiating to the epigastrium. Which of the following condition is most likely to be 
associated with this finding?
questions.explanation:
A holosystolic murmur that is best heard over the lower left sternal border and radiating to the 
epigastrium most likely arises from tricuspid regurgitation.

questions.question: Question 27: Which of the following is true about Still’s murmur?

options.a: It is heard in mitral regurgitation
options.b: It is best heard in left lateral decubitus position

questions.explanation:
Still’s murmur refers to the benign grade 2 mid-systolic murmur heard at mid or lower left sternal 
border in normal children and adolescents. Louder in hyperdynamic states(fever, anxiety). The anatomic basis for the murmur has not been definitively determined. It is best heard in 
a supine position.

questions.question: Question 28: Graham Steell murmur is heard in?
questions.explanation:
Graham Steell murmur is the early to mid-diastolic murmur heard in pulmonary regurgitation. It is best heard in 2nd left intercostal space and radiates along left sternal border. It can increase 
with inspiration.

questions.question: Question 29: Carey Coombs murmur is heard in?
questions.explanation:
Carey Coombs murmur is heard in mitral valvulitis. It is a mid-diastolic murmur heard during an episode of acute rheumatic fever causing mitral 
valvulitis. It is produced due to the flow of blood through an edematous mitral valve and dissipates with the 
resolution of the acute attack.

questions.question: Question 30: Austin-Flint murmur is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Austin-Flint murmur is a low-pitched mid to late diastolic murmur of chronic severe AR. It results from the turbulence at the mitral inflow area from the mixture of regurgitant and 
forward blood flow. It is best heard at the apex. 801

questions.question:
Question 31: A 60-year-old man presented with an episode of acute onset dizziness and loss of 
consciousness which lasted for a few seconds followed by a regain of full consciousness. There 
were no similar episodes in the past. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this 
scenario?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of transient loss of consciousness in this patient is suggestive of syncope. 
Hence, an ECG must be done to rule out cardiac causes for syncope like - arrhythmias (atrial 
fibrillation, sinus node dysfunction, supra ventricular tachycardias) or a structural cardiac 
abnormality. A CT would only be required if a seizure or transient ischemic attack (TIA) is suspected. However, 
in this case - the episode only lasted for a few seconds, the patient has no history of similar 
episodes in the past and there are no lasting neurological deficits after the episode. Therefore, 
option B is incorrect. Syncope is a transient loss of consciousness caused by global cerebral hypoperfusion. It can be 
due to multiple causes, but is broadly divided into - neurally mediated syncope, orthostatic 
hypotension and cardiac syncope. The initial workup for a case of syncope includes: • Detailed history of the episode and past history of similar episodes • Physical examination mainly to check BP in standing and supine positions to • rule out orthostatic hypotension. • A resting ECG to look for cardiac arrhythmia • Option B: If the ECG is normal, no further tests are needed. If the ECG is suggestive of cardiac 
arrhythmia, then further tests including continuous ECG monitoring and electrophysiological 
studies may be done. Option C: Tilt-table testing is done in patients with recurrent syncopal attacks who are suspected 
to have vasovagal syncope. Psychiatric evaluation is done in patients with recurrent unexplained 
syncopal attacks. Option D: Vestibular neuritis is associated with vertigo, where the patients typically complain of 
dizziness and a sense of spinning of the head. 802 
Sold by @itachibot ECG Basics
